feed.title: JosephKimiri's Blog
feed.subtitle: My name is Joseph Kimiri, a passionate individual immersed in the world of cybersecurity. As a CTF player, I thrive in the challenge of hacking, defending, and analyzing computer systems and networks. With a bug bounty hunter mindset, I actively seek out vulnerabilities in software, websites, and applications, helping organizations strengthen their security posture. Armed with my expertise in penetration testing, I conduct thorough assessments, pinpointing weaknesses and providing recommendations for fortifying defenses. In the realm of cybersecurity, I am a relentless protector of digital assets, dedicated to ensuring safety and preserving integrity.

entry.title: Exploiting exposed SVN folder for Account Takeover

link.title: Exploiting exposed SVN folder for Account Takeover

entry.summary:
Unveiling the Consequences of Subversion Disclosure : A Tale of Account TAkeover
What is Subversion?
Subversion, often referred to as SVN, is a centralized version control system that was initially released in 2000. It is developed and maintained by the web server software platform Apache. Unlike Git, which operates on a distributed model, SVN functions as a centralized system and is also op...

entry.title: Secured Notes
entry.summary:
Secured Notes I created an application to retrieve my secrets. Is it realy secured? SecuredNotes.apk
Solution Here, we were given an apkfile and we were tasked into finding whether the app was handling secrets well. I decompiled the app using apktool using the command apktool d SecuredNotes.apk
I then went into the folder containing the application and grepped for the key words secret &amp...

Web
For the web challenges, I solved one challenge by the name Graph1.
Graph1 We are given a link and told to find the flag.
I was happy I had an opportunity to learn how graphql works. You can learn more about graphql testing here

entry.title: Pico CTF (ReadMyCert)
entry.summary:
ReadMyCert
AUTHOR: SUNDAY JACOB NWANYIM
Description How about we take you on an adventure on exploring certificate signing requests Take a look at this CSR file here
Solution
